title: Sow peas over winter for a tasty spring crop
text:
Gardening expert and no-dig allotmenteer Jack Wallington provides weekly advice on how to grow food yourself

As well as admiring yellowing leaves, I spend autumn observing its remarkable similarities with spring. Warm, damp soils make for ideal growing conditions and it’s in autumn that many plants undergo their most complex transformation, forming new buds and growing points ready for next year (called meristems, the happiest of botanical words).

You’ll also spot weed seedlings sprouting, indicating that conditions are perfect for germinating overwintering vegetables, such as peas. Having tried various varieties, the one I currently recommend is ‘Meteor’ (chilternseeds.co.uk). It performs...
